channel.title: Project on IN104 - MiniWolfram
channel.description: Recent content in Project on IN104 - MiniWolfram

item.title: First step
item.description: Download the project files You can download the provided files directly from the GitHub repository by using the following command: git clone https://github.com/TurtleSmoke/IN104.gitCreate a new repository After downloading the repository, the next step is to create a new private repository on your GitHub account. Then, you’ll need to update the remote URL of your local repository to link it with the newly created repository. This can be done by executing the following commands:

item.title: Description
item.description: Note Before starting the project, please follow the instructions in the first step to download the provided files and create a new repository. Overview The project is focused on creating a simplified version of Wolfram Alpha starting with the implementation of a basic calculator. This baseline calculator must be capable of handling the following operations: Addition Subtraction Multiplication Division Modulus Additionally, the calculator must handle parentheses and spaces within expressions.

item.title: Provided files
item.description: Provided files To help you get started, we have provided a utils file containing the following structures: TokenType: An enumeration representing the different types of tokens. Token: A structure representing a token. TokenQueue: A structure representing a queue of tokens. TokenStack: A structure representing a stack of tokens. Token types The TokenType enumeration contains the following token types: typedef enum { NUMBER = 0, ADD, SUB, MUL, DIV, MOD, LEFT_PAREN, RIGHT_PAREN, } TokenType;You can use this enumeration to identify the type of each token in the input string.

item.title: Additional Resources
item.description: Additional resources Here are some additional resources that you may find useful for this project: Example of good README Why you should use Git How to correctly commit Commits convention Test-Driven Development What is test-driven development (TDD)? Test Driven Development Unit testing Better Unit Testing Formatting your code Pre-commit hooks
